title: Convincing Catalytic Chemists: Progress Towards Matching In-Situ Gas Phase Microscopy to the Benchtop
content: Heterogeneous catalysis plays a pivotal role in many sectors, including energy production and environmental sustainability. Thus, development of efficient, environmentally friendly, catalyst materials is a central area of technological development and research. Optimization of these materials requires meticulous characterization of the underlying nanoscale processes and mechanisms which control the catalystsâ€™ selectivity, activity, and stability. High-resolution characterization of the atomic structure is typically carried out using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), however, conventional, static TEM imaging lacks the temporal, dynamic information necessary to accurately interpret active-state catalyst behavior [1].
